questions.text: Among the following, which molecule is required for the presentation of the antigens by the APCs to TH2 cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) MHC

Explanation:

  • Antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells play a crucial role in the adaptive immune response by presenting antigens to T-helper (TH2) cells.
  • This process requires Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) Class II molecules, which are essential for the activation of CD4+ T cells, including TH2 cells.
  • MHC Molecule Role: APCs process antigens and present them on their surface bound to MHC Class II molecules. MHC Class II molecules interact with the T-cell receptor (TCR) on CD4+ T cells. This interaction is critical for the differentiation and activation of TH2 cells, which secrete cytokines to mediate humoral immunity.

Incorrect Options:

NK cells (Option A) are part of the innate immune system and do not present antigens or directly interact with TH2 cells.

G-protein coupled receptors (Option B) are involved in cell signalling but are not involved in antigen presentation to T cells.

Lectin receptors (Option D) are involved in innate immune recognition, particularly of carbohydrate molecules, but they do not mediate antigen presentation to TH2 cells.

questions.text: Which of the following types of cell death involves activation of caspase enzymes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Apoptosis and Pyroptosis

Explanation:

Apoptosis and Pyroptosis involves activation of caspase enzymes.

Apoptosis

  • A tightly regulated suicide program where cells activate enzymes to degrade their DNA and proteins.
  • It’s an active process eliminating irreparably damaged cells without causing inflammation or tissue damage.
  • Driven by activation of caspases that cause DNA fragmentation
  • Phases: (Option B)
    • Initiation phase: Activation of caspases 8, 9, 10 triggers a cascade.
    • Execution phase: Terminal caspases 3, 6, 7 lead to cellular breakdown.
  • Morphological features:
    • Cell shrinkage
    • Chromatin condensation
    • Cytoplasmic blebs and formation of apoptotic bodies
    • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies by macrophages
  • Histopathology: Apoptotic cells appear as round/oval with intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm and dense nuclear chromatin fragments.

Pyroptosis

  • It is a form of programmed cell death involving release of IL-1, a fever-inducing cytokine.
  • Microbial products in cells activate the inflammasome complex.
  • Inflammasome activates caspase-1, which converts inactive IL-1 to active IL-1. (Option B)
  • Active IL-1 causes fever, inflammation, and leukocyte recruitment.
  • Pyroptosis helps eliminate infected cells and triggers local inflammation.

Necrosis (Option A) is a form of accidental cell death that does not involve caspases.

Necroptosis (Option C) is a programmed form of necrosis that occurs independently of caspases.

questions.text: A diabetic male presented with seizures. Radiological examination shows a lesion. Histopathological examination shows liquefactive necrosis. What is the most important mechanism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Enzymatic degradation.

Explanation:

  • Diabetic patient with seizures → raises suspicion for a brain lesion (possibly abscess, infarct, or infection-related pathology).
  • Histopathology: liquefactive necrosis → classic type of necrosis seen in brain tissue.
  • Liquefactive necrosis in brain is mainly due to hydrolytic enzyme action breaking down tissue.
  • In the CNS, ischemia or infection activates microglia and infiltrating neutrophils.
  • These cells release lysosomal hydrolytic enzymes.
  • Brain tissue is rich in lipids and has little structural stroma, so enzymatic digestion quickly converts tissue into a liquid mass.
  • Mechanism: enzymatic degradation > structural breakdown → liquefactive necrosis.

Mechanical (Option B): Trauma can cause hemorrhage or contusion, but necrosis type is not primarily from mechanical injury alone, here histology points to enzymatic breakdown.

Ischemic (Option C): Ischemia in most organs causes coagulative necrosis, except in the brain, where it still leads to liquefactive necrosis, but the mechanism is enzymatic digestion, not ischemia per se.

Pressure (Option D): Increased intracranial pressure can cause herniation or atrophy, not liquefactive necrosis by itself.

questions.text: Which of the following is pro-apoptotic?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Bax:

Explanation:

The correct answer is Bax, because it is a pro-apoptotic member of the Bcl-2 protein family.

  • The Bcl-2 family regulates the intrinsic (mitochondrial) apoptosis pathway.
  • Members are divided into:
    • Anti-apoptotic: Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, Mcl-1 → preserve mitochondrial membrane integrity, prevent cytochrome c release.
    • Pro-apoptotic: Bax, Bak, Bok → promote mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilisation (MOMP), allowing cytochrome c release and caspase activation.

Mnemonic:

  • "Bax and Bak Break" (break the mitochondrial membrane) → pro-apoptotic.
  • "Bcl and Bcl-xL Build" (preserve the membrane) → anti-apoptotic.

questions.text: Caspase-1 is primarily involved in which type of programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Pyroptosis

Explanation:

Caspase-1 plays a central role in Pyroptosis, a form of programmed cell death associated with inflammation.

  • It is a form of apoptosis in which there is release of the fever-inducing cytokine IL-1.
  • Microbial products entering infected cells are recognized by cytoplasmic receptors,
  • activating the multiprotein complex inflammasome.
  • This complex activates caspase 1 which converts the inactive IL-1 to active IL-1, causing fever, inflammation and leucocyte recruitment. (Option B)
  • Pyroptosis is the mechanism by which some microbes cause the death of infected cells and trigger local inflammation.

 

Apoptosis (Option A) is a controlled, non-inflammatory cell death involving caspases-8, -9, -3, and -7, but not caspase-1, and serves to remove damaged cells without triggering an immune response.

Necroptosis (Option C) is a programmed inflammatory cell death triggered when apoptosis is blocked, involving RIPK1, RIPK3, and MLKL—but not caspase-1, distinguishing it from pyroptosis.

Necrosis (Option D) is an uncontrolled, non-programmed cell death due to injury (e.g., trauma or ischemia), causing inflammation without involving caspases, including caspase-1.

questions.text: What is the mechanism for healing in the case of a 57-year-old male with a gradually developing swelling over the scalp region, pus discharge, and pain?
questions.solution:
Correct option: C

  • In this case, the mechanism for healing is granulation tissue formation. Granulation tissue is a type of connective tissue that forms during the healing process of a wound. It is composed of new blood vessels (angiogenesis), fibroblasts, and an extracellular matrix. Granulation tissue fills the wound defect and helps in the formation of new tissue. It appears as red, soft, and granular tissue on the wound surface.

Incorrect options:

Option A: Granuloma formation: Granuloma formation is a type of chronic inflammation characterized by the aggregation of immune cells, typically macrophages, in response to persistent or resistant antigens. It is not the primary mechanism involved in the healing of the described wound.

Option B: Scab formation: Scab formation occurs during the initial stages of wound healing when blood components, such as fibrin and platelets, dry and form a protective crust over the wound. It is not the primary mechanism involved in the healing process after incision and drainage of an infected scalp swelling.

Option D: Neovascularization: Neovascularization refers to the formation of new blood vessels. It is an important step in wound healing, but in the context of the described case, granulation tissue formation is a more relevant mechanism for healing.

questions.text: The body of an 82-year-old man has been seen for a post-mortem to determine the cause of death. You are examining a histopathological slide containing a section of his cardiac tissue where you notice some pigmentation. Which is the substance that is seen in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lipofuscin

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image shows lipofuscin in the section of cardiac tissue.
  • Lipofuscin is a yellow to red-brown pigment found in cardiac muscle cells, particularly around the nucleus in the hearts of elderly, debilitated people.

Melanin (Option A) is a black or brown pigment found in skin, hair, and certain brain areas, not typically seen in cardiac tissue.

Hemosiderin (Option C) is an iron-storage complex resulting from the breakdown of haemoglobin, typically associated with conditions like haemorrhage or hemochromatosis.

Iron (Option D): Elemental iron deposition in tissues is pathological and associated with diseases like hemochromatosis or chronic blood transfusions. Staining with Prussian blue would help confirm iron presence.

questions.text: Apoptotic bodies comprise of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Include cytoplasm + intranuclear material + organelle

Explanation:

  • Apoptotic bodies are comprised of cytoplasm, intranuclear material and cellular organelles.

Apoptosis (caspase-dependent programmed cell death):

  • It is a type of cell death that is induced by a tightly regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells’ genomic DNA and nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.
  • It is an active process.
  • It eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction, thus limiting collateral tissue damage.
  • Apoptosis results from the activation of enzymes called caspases, which leads to DNA fragmentation.
  • The process of apoptosis may be divided into:
    • Initiation phase: Caspases 8,9,10 become catalytically active and unleash a cascade of other caspase
    • Execution phase: During which the terminal caspases 3,6,7 trigger cellular fragmentation.

Morphological features:-

  • Cell shrinkage
  • Chromatin condensation
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies (cytoplasm and tightly packed organelles, with or without nuclear fragments) (Option A)
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies, usually by macrophages.

Histopathology:

  • The apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.

The cell is reduced in size and contains brightly eosinophilic cytoplasm and a condensed nucleus.

Types:

Apoptosis occurs in two broad contexts:

  • Physiological apoptosis.
  • Pathological apoptosis.

Physiological Apoptosis

Pathological Apoptosis
  • The removal of supernumerary cells (in excess of the required number) during development.
  • Involution of hormone-dependent tissues on hormone withdrawal, such as endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle.
  • Elimination of potentially harmful self-reactive lymphocytes to prevent immune reactions against one’s own tissues.
  • Death of host cells that have served their useful purpose, such as neutrophils in an acute inflammatory response and lymphocytes at the end of an immune response.
  • DNA damage.
  • Accumulation of misfolded proteins
  • Apoptosis can be induced during certain infections- as in adenovirus and HIV infections and viral hepatitis.
  • It may also contribute to pathologic atrophy in parenchymal organs after duct obstruction, such as occurs in the pancreas, parotid gland, and kidney.

questions.text: Which of the following caspases binds to Cyt c and the APAF-1 complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Caspase 9

Explanation:

  • In the intrinsic apoptotic pathway, the release of cytochrome c (Cyt c) from the mitochondria triggers the formation of the apoptosome, a complex consisting of Cyt c, apoptotic protease-activating factor 1 (APAF-1), and procaspase 9. This complex is essential for initiating the caspase cascade that leads to cell death.

 

Apoptosis (Caspase-dependent programmed cell death):

  • Apoptosis is a type of cell death that is induced by a tightly regulated suicide program in which cells destined to die activate intrinsic enzymes that degrade the cells’ genomic DNA and nuclear and cytoplasmic proteins.
  • It is an active process.
  • It eliminates cells that are injured beyond repair without eliciting a host reaction, thus limiting collateral tissue damage.
  • Apoptosis results from activating enzymes called caspases, leading to DNA fragmentation.
  • The process of apoptosis may be divided into an initiation phase, during which caspases 8,9,10 become catalytically active and unleash a cascade of other caspases, and an execution phase, during which the terminal caspases 3,6,7 trigger cellular fragmentation.
     

Morphological features:-

  • Cell shrinkage
  • Chromatin condensation
  • Formation of cytoplasmic blebs and apoptotic bodies
  • Phagocytosis of apoptotic bodies, usually by macrophages.


Histopathology: In H&E-stained tissue, the apoptotic cell appears as a round or oval mass of intensely eosinophilic cytoplasm with fragments of dense nuclear chromatin.

The above image shows apoptosis of an epidermal cell in an immune reaction. The cell is reduced in size and contains brightly eosinophilic cytoplasm and a condensed nucleus

 

Types:

Apoptosis occurs in two broad contexts:

  • Physiological apoptosis.
  • Pathological apoptosis.

Apoptosis in physiological conditions 

Apoptosis in pathological conditions

1. The removal of supernumerary cells (in excess of the required number) during development.

2. Involution of hormone-dependent tissues on hormone withdrawal, such as endometrial cell breakdown during the menstrual cycle.

3. Elimination of potentially harmful self-reactive lymphocytes to prevent immune reactions against one’s own tissues.

4. Death of host cells that have served their useful purpose, such as neutrophils in an acute inflammatory response and lymphocytes at the end of an immune response.

1. DNA damage.

2. Accumulation of misfolded proteins

3. Apoptosis can be induced during infections such as adenovirus, HIV, and viral hepatitis.

4. It may also contribute to pathologic atrophy in parenchymal organs after duct obstruction, such as occurs in the pancreas, parotid gland, and kidney

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Methanol

Explanation:

Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

Fixatives are chemicals that preserve biological tissues by stabilizing cellular structures and preventing decay or degradation. The goal is to maintain the tissue in a life-like state as much as possible for microscopic examination.

  • Fixation helps maintain the tissue's integrity by preventing autolysis (self-digestion) and putrefaction (bacterial decay).
  • Crosslinking Fixatives: These fixatives work by forming covalent bonds between the proteins and other cellular structures, effectively "locking" them in place. This preserves the tissue’s structural integrity.
    • Formaldehyde (Option B): Most commonly used in the form of 10% neutral-buffered formalin.
    • Glutaraldehyde (Option A): Often used for electron microscopy due to its ability to preserve fine cellular structures.
    • Osmium tetroxide (Option D): Used primarily for electron microscopy, particularly for preserving lipids and membranes.
  • Precipitating Fixatives: These work by precipitating proteins and other cellular components, which makes them less soluble and helps preserve their structure.
    • Methanol
    • Ethanol
  • Additive Fixatives: They chemically bind to tissue components, such as proteins or nucleic acids, and stabilize them. They are typically more gentle and produce better preservation of ultrastructure.
    • Formaldehyde
    • Glutaraldehyde
  • Non-Additive Fixatives:
    • Alcohol
    • Acetone

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with increasing abdominal girth. On examination, shifting dullness was present, and the liver span was less than 7cm. Histopathological examination revealed the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes. What is the content of these inclusions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Intermediate filaments

Explanation:

  • The presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes is a key finding in alcoholic liver disease.
  • Mallory-Denk bodies or Mallory hyaline bodies are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions composed of intermediate filaments, particularly cytokeratin 8 and 18, commonly seen in hepatocytes in conditions such as alcoholic liver disease.
  • Conditions where Mallory Hyaline bodies are seen are (Mnemonic: New Indian WATCH)
    • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
    • Indian childhood cirrhosis
    • Wilson’s disease
    • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency; Alcoholic Liver Disease
    • Tumor of the liver (Hepatocellular carcinoma)
    • Chronic Cholestatic conditions
    • Hepatic or Primary Biliary cirrhosis (not seen in Secondary biliary cirrhosis)

 

 

Actin (Option B) is a structural protein found in microfilaments but does not typically form eosinophilic inclusions in alcoholic liver disease.

Microtubules (Option C) are involved in intracellular transport and cell division but do not form eosinophilic inclusions in hepatocytes.

Fibronectin (Option D) is an extracellular matrix protein, and although it plays a role in tissue repair and scarring, it is not associated with the formation of intracytoplasmic inclusions in liver cells, especially in alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient presented with cough, fatigue, and weight loss. He was diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma on bronchoscopy. The resected specimen had a hilar lymph node that was 1 cm in size and showed a black pigment. What is the black pigment likely to be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Anthracotic pigment

Explanation:

  • Anthracotic pigment is a black, carbon-based pigment commonly seen in lymph nodes and lungs, as well as in individuals with chronic smoking or environmental pollution exposure.
  • These particles are engulfed by macrophages in the lungs and then transported to nearby lymph nodes, often leading to anthracosis.
  • HPE shows carbon-laden macrophages.
  • In patients with lung cancer, particularly squamous cell carcinoma, the presence of hilar lymphadenopathy and black pigment is a common finding due to the direct proximity of the lungs and lymphatic drainage of carbon particles.


Melanin (Option B) is responsible for skin and hair pigmentation and protects against UV radiation. While it can sometimes be found in melanomas (a type of skin cancer), it is not typically found in the lungs or lymph nodes.

 

Lipochrome (Option C) is a group of yellow to brown pigments that arise from the breakdown of lipids (fats). On microscopy, it appears as a yellow-brown, finely granular cytoplasmic pigment, often deposited in the perinuclear location. These pigments can be found in various tissues but are not typically associated with lung diseases or lymph node involvement.

 

Hemosiderin (Option D) is an iron-containing pigment derived from the breakdown of hemoglobin. While hemosiderin can appear brown, it does not appear as a black pigment in the context of smoking-related lung disease or cancer.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male was brought to the emergency department after suffering severe injuries in a motorcycle accident. His blood pressure was 80/60 mm Hg, and he was tachycardic with cold, clammy skin. An ultrasound examination revealed a ruptured spleen. Arterial blood gas analysis was suggestive of metabolic acidosis. Which of the following conditions most likely caused the patient to suffer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypovolemic shock

Explanation:

Hypovolemic shock occurs due to significant blood or fluid loss, leading to reduced blood volume and inadequate tissue perfusion. This patient’s low blood pressure, tachycardia, cold, clammy skin, and metabolic acidosis suggest shock caused by blood loss from the ruptured spleen.

  • Shock is a state of circulatory failure that impairs tissue perfusion and leads to cellular hypoxia. Initially, cellular injury is reversible, but prolonged shock can cause irreversible tissue damage and may be fatal.
  • It can result from various conditions, such as severe haemorrhage, extensive trauma, burns, myocardial infarction, pulmonary embolism, and microbial sepsis. The causes of shock can be categorised into three main types:
    • Cardiogenic shock: (Option A)
      • Caused by low cardiac output due to myocardial pump failure.
      • This may result from intrinsic myocardial damage (e.g., infarction), ventricular arrhythmias, extrinsic compression (e.g., cardiac tamponade), or outflow obstruction (e.g., pulmonary embolism).
    • Hypovolemic shock:
      • Occurs due to low blood volume, often from massive haemorrhage or fluid loss (e.g., severe burns).
      • This leads to reduced cardiac output and impaired tissue perfusion.
    • Septic shock: (Option B)
      • Sepsis: Life-threatening organ dysfunction due to a dysregulated host response to infection.
      • Septic Shock: A subset of sepsis with profound circulatory, cellular, and metabolic abnormalities that increase mortality risk.
      • Systemic Inflammatory Response Syndrome (SIRS): A sepsis-like condition triggered by non-microbial insults, such as burns, trauma, or pancreatitis. Both SIRS and septic shock are marked by a massive release of inflammatory mediators, causing arterial vasodilation, vascular leakage, and venous blood pooling, leading to tissue hypoperfusion, cellular hypoxia, and organ dysfunction.
  • Neurogenic Shock (Option D): Occurs following spinal cord injury, leading to acute vasodilation and hypotension.
  • Anaphylactic Shock: Caused by an IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction, resulting in acute vasodilation, hypotension, and tissue hypoperfusion.

questions.text:
Identify the correct statements regarding amyloidosis.


	Amyloidosis is called so because it looks like the deposition of starch.
	Beta-pleated sheets are seen.
	AL is a type of secondary amyloidosis.
	It is an extracellular protein.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2 and 4

Explanation:

  • Amyloidosis is a group of disorders characterized by the extracellular deposition of amyloid fibrils that are produced by the aggregation of misfolded proteins. (Statement 4)
  • The presence of abundant charged sugar groups in these adsorbed proteins gives the deposits staining characteristics that were thought to resemble starch (amylose). Therefore, the deposits were called amyloid (Statement 1).
  • 95% of amyloid consists of fibril proteins, with the remaining 5% being glycosaminoglycans (dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate) and plasma proteins, notably serum amyloid P.
  • AL amyloidosis is a primary form of amyloidosis, whereas secondary form can be caused by various etiologies and is associated with characteristic amyloid deposition (Statement 3).
  • Physical nature of amyloid:
  • Light microscopy with H & E stains: Amyloid is an amorphous, eosinophilic, hyaline, and extracellular substance.

  • Electron microscopy: All types of amyloid, regardless of clinical setting or chemical composition, consist of continuous, nonbranching fibrils with a diameter of approximately 7.5 to 10 nm.
  • X-ray crystallography and infrared spectroscopy: Characteristic cross-β-pleated sheet conformation, which is responsible for the distinctive Congo-red staining and apple-green birefringence of the amyloid. (Statement 2)

questions.text: Which type of amyloidosis is seen in patients undergoing dialysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) β2-microglobulin

Explanation:

In dialysis patients, the most common amyloidosis is β2-microglobulin-associated amyloidosis (dialysis-related amyloidosis, DRA). Normally cleared by the kidneys, β2-microglobulin accumulates in dialysis patients,

Important amyloid-disease associations

Disease

Amyloid

Multiple myeloma and other monoclonal plasma cell disorders

AL (Option D ruled out)

Chronic inflammation

AA

Alzheimer’s disease

Aβ (Option A ruled out)

Familial amyloid polyneuropathy

ATTR (mutated form of transthyretin) (Option C ruled out)

Diabetes mellitus

AIAPP

Hemodialysis associated amyloidosis

Aβ2m (Option B)

Familial Mediterranean Fever

AA

Senile systemic amyloidosis

ATTR (Increased quantity of TTR, no mutation is seen)

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid

Acal

Isolated atrial amyloidosis

AANF

leading to amyloid fibril deposition in bones and joints, causing pain, stiffness, and deformities.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is caused by abnormal folding of proteins?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Creutzfelt Jakob disease

Explanation:

  • Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a type of prion disease caused by the abnormal folding of proteins, specifically prion proteins (PrP), which leads to neurodegeneration.
  • It is irreversible and fatal.
  • The disease progresses quickly, and death usually occurs within a year.
  • It is characterised by
    • Rapidly progressive dementia
    • Myoclonus
    • Ataxia
    • Visual disturbances
  • Diagnosis: It is confirmed via MRI (increased signal in basal ganglia) and EEG findings

Cirrhosis (Option B) is liver scarring typically caused by chronic liver diseases (e.g., hepatitis, alcoholism), not protein misfolding.

Nephritic syndrome (Option C) is a kidney disorder involving inflammation, typically due to immune complex deposition, not protein misfolding.

Sickle cell anaemia (Option D) is caused by a genetic mutation in the haemoglobin gene (HbS) that leads to abnormal haemoglobin, but not a misfolding of proteins in the same sense as prion diseases.

questions.text:
Which of the following are features describing necrosis?


	Cell swelling
	Disrupted cell membrane
	Induces inflammation
	Physiological
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

  • Necrosis is a form of pathological cell death (Statement 4 ruled out), often occurring due to various injuries, such as physical trauma, ischemia, infection, or exposure to toxic substances.
  • It is characterized by cell swelling, membrane rupture, organelle damage, and nuclear changes (Pyknosis, Karyorrhexis, Karyolysis).
  • Cell swelling occurs because of the loss of cellular integrity and failure of ion pumps (such as the Na+/K+ ATPase pump), leading to an influx of water into the cell.
  • In necrosis, the plasma membrane of the cell is disrupted, allowing the release of intracellular contents.
  • The released substances trigger an immune response, leading to an inflammatory reaction, which is a characteristic of necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic gene?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) MCL1

Explanation:

  • MCL1 is an anti-apoptotic gene and part of the BCL-2 family.
  • Apoptosis is a key process for maintaining cell balance and eliminating damaged cells, regulated by the interplay between pro-apoptotic and anti-apoptotic genes.
  • MCL1 inhibits apoptosis by preventing the activation of pro-apoptotic proteins, thereby promoting cell survival.

Apoptotic genes:

  • Anti Apoptotic genes :- BCL-2 , BCL-XL , MCL-1
  • Pro Apoptotic genes:- BAX and BAK (Option A ruled out)
  • Apoptosis initiators:- BAD, BIM, BID, Noxa and Puma (Option C & D ruled out)

questions.text: All are features of irreversible injury except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Blebs formation:

  • Blebs formation is actually a characteristic feature of reversible cell injury, not irreversible injury. Blebs are small, bubble-like protrusions on the cell membrane that result from cytoskeletal and membrane alterations. They can be observed in conditions like ischemia and toxic injury. Reversibility implies that the cell can recover its normal structure and function when the damaging stimulus is removed.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Karyolysis: Karyolysis refers to the dissolution of the cell nucleus due to DNA degradation. This is indeed a feature of irreversible cell injury. In irreversible injury, the cell's nuclear structure and DNA integrity are compromised beyond repair, leading to processes like karyolysis.

Option C - Amorphous Densities: The presence of amorphous densities is often associated with irreversible cell injury. These densities can be observed under electron microscopy and represent aggregates of denatured or altered proteins, lipids, and other cellular components. They are a sign of severe damage and cell death.

Option D - Pyknotic Nucleus: Pyknosis is the irreversible condensation of chromatin within the nucleus, resulting in a small, darkly stained and shrunken nucleus. This is indeed a feature of irreversible cell injury. Pyknotic nuclei indicate severe cellular damage that cannot be reversed, leading to cell death.

questions.text: Senile atrophy occurs due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Chronic ischemia from progressive arterial occlusion leads to tissue atrophy. In older adults, reduced cerebral blood flow due to atherosclerosis causes senile atrophy of the brain.

 

Loss of innervation (denervation atrophy) (Option A): Skeletal muscle metabolism and function rely on nerve supply. Damage to the nerves results in atrophy of the muscle fibres they innervate.

Inadequate nutrition (Option B): Severe protein-calorie malnutrition, such as marasmus, causes the breakdown of skeletal muscle proteins for energy after fat stores are depleted, leading to muscle wasting (cachexia). This is common in chronic inflammatory diseases and cancer. In cachectic states, excessive TNF production contributes to appetite suppression and lipid depletion, further exacerbating muscle atrophy.

Decreased workload (disuse atrophy) (Option C): Immobilization of bones, such as through a plaster cast or prolonged bed rest, leads to rapid muscle atrophy. Initially, the decrease in cell size is reversible upon resumption of activity. However, with prolonged disuse, muscle fibres shrink in size and number (due to apoptosis), and muscle atrophy may be accompanied by increased bone resorption, resulting in disuse osteoporosis.

questions.text: Cell-in-cell appearance is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Entosis refers to the process where one cell is engulfed by another, leading to a "cell-in-cell" appearance.

 

Entosis:

  • It refers to a homotypic process where one epithelial cell invades the cytoplasm of another epithelial cell.
  • The host cell forms a vacuole around the internalized cell, which deforms its organelles, including the nucleus.
  • The inner cell may survive within the host cell for up to 12 hours or longer, eventually being digested by the outer cell through an autophagosomal mechanism, or it may escape.

Necrosis (Option A) is an uncontrolled form of cell death characterized by cell swelling, rupture, and inflammation.

 

Apoptosis (Option B) is a controlled, programmed cell death where cells shrink and fragment into apoptotic bodies.

 

Necroptosis (Option C) is a form of regulated cell death that mimics necrosis but is genetically controlled. Unlike apoptosis, it is associated with inflammation and occurs via receptor-interacting protein kinases (RIPK1 and RIPK3), leading to membrane rupture and the release of intracellular contents.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding sirtuins?


	Increases insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism
	Promotes genes that increase longevity
	They are of 7 types
	They are one of the types of histone deacetylases
questions.solution:
• Sirtuins are NAD-dependent protein deacetylases. (Statement 4)
  • Seven types (Statement 3) of sirtuins exist in mammals, each with unique functions.
  • They help the body adapt to environmental stresses like food deprivation and DNA damage.
  • Longevity: Sirtuins promote genes that increase longevity (Statement 2), reduce metabolism, inhibit apoptosis, and protect against oxidative damage.
  • Sirtuins enhance insulin sensitivity and glucose metabolism (Statement 1)
  • Caloric restriction: Increases sirtuin activity, reducing IGF-1 signalling, leading to slower cell growth, reduced metabolism, and cellular damage.
  • Sirtuin-6: Plays a key role in metabolic adaptations and DNA repair by activating repair enzymes.
  • Anti-ageing: Sirtuins are linked to anti-ageing effects.
  • Red wine: A compound in red wine is believed to activate sirtuins, potentially contributing to increased lifespan.

questions.text: Supravital stains are used in the identification of all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Copper in tissue

Explanation:

  • Supravital stains are typically used to identify cellular components such as reticulocytes (immature red blood cells), Heinz bodies (denatured haemoglobin), and ribosomal RNA (which is seen in reticulocytes as a network). However, copper in tissue is not identified using supravital stains; it requires special staining techniques like rhodanine stains.

questions.text: All of the following are signs of reversible cell injury, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Dense mitochondrial deposit:

  • Mitochondrial changes, such as swelling and dysfunction, are associated with irreversible cell injury.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and C are associated with reversible cell injury.

questions.text: Which of the following ions is involved in cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Calcium:

  • Calcium ions play a significant role in cell injury.
  • Increased intracellular calcium levels can trigger several damaging processes within the cell.
  • Excessive calcium influx into the cell can lead to mitochondrial dysfunction, activation of enzymes that degrade cellular components, and disruption of cell membrane integrity.
  • These processes can ultimately result in cell death.

Incorrect Options: 

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Liquefactive necrosis is seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Brain:

  • Liquefactive necrosis is characterized by the dissolution of affected cells, resulting in a liquid, viscous appearance.
  • It typically occurs in organs with abundant enzyme activity and limited structural support, such as the brain.
  • In the brain, this form of necrosis can be observed in cases of cerebral infarction or abscess formation.
  • The liquefied material is often composed of dead cells, tissue debris, and inflammatory cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Heart: The most common type of cell death seen in the heart is coagulative necrosis.

Option C - Lungs: The lungs are prone to different types of necrosis, including coagulative necrosis in response to infarction and caseous necrosis in certain infections like tuberculosis.

Option D - Kidney: Renal tissue is susceptible to ischemic injury, leading to coagulative necrosis in most cases.

questions.text: Identify the anti-apoptotic factor among the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bcl-2:

  • Bcl-2 (B-cell lymphoma 2) is an anti-apoptotic protein that plays a key role in regulating cell survival.
  • It functions by inhibiting apoptosis.
  • Bcl-2 prevents the release of cytochrome c from the mitochondria, which is a crucial step in the initiation of apoptosis.
  • By inhibiting cytochrome c release, Bcl-2 helps to maintain cell survival and prevent apoptosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - p53:

  • p53 is an apoptotic factor.
  • p53 is a tumor suppressor protein that plays a role in promoting apoptosis in response to DNA damage or other cellular stresses.

Option B - KRAS:

  • KRAS is an oncogene that is involved in promoting cell proliferation and survival.

Option D - BAK:

  • BAK is a pro-apoptotic factor belonging to the Bcl-2 family.
  • BAK promotes apoptosis by inducing mitochondrial outer membrane permeabilization, leading to cytochrome c release and activation of the apoptotic cascade.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fibrinoid necrosis:

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa.
  • In this condition, immune complexes and inflammatory cells infiltrate the vessel walls, causing damage and necrosis.
  • The deposition of fibrin-like proteinaceous material leads to thickening and an eosinophilic appearance of the vessel walls.
  • Fibrinoid necrosis is a characteristic finding in autoimmune diseases affecting blood vessels.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Gangrenous necrosis:

  • Gangrenous necrosis typically occurs in ischemic or infected tissues.
  • It is characterized by dry or wet gangrene, depending on the presence of bacterial infection and tissue liquefaction.

Option C - Fat necrosis:

  • Fat necrosis occurs in adipose tissue and is often associated with conditions like acute pancreatitis or trauma.
  • It involves the breakdown of fat cells by pancreatic enzymes, leading to the release of fatty acids and the formation of necrotic areas.

Option D - Caseous necrosis:

  • Caseous necrosis is commonly associated with tuberculosis and other granulomatous infections.
  • It is characterized by the formation of a granular, cheese-like necrotic material within the affected tissue.

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of Bcl-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Follicular lymphoma:

  • Follicular lymphoma is strongly associated with the overexpression of Bcl-2.
  • In follicular lymphoma, there is a genetic translocation [most commonly t(14;18)] that leads to the overexpression of the Bcl-2 protein.
  • This overexpression of Bcl-2 helps the cancer cells evade apoptosis, contributing to their uncontrolled growth and survival.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are not associated with overexpression of Bcl-2.

questions.text: Metastatic calcification occurs in all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Atheroma:

  • The type of calcification seen in atheroma is dystrophic calcification.
  • Metastatic calcification:
    • Metastatic calcification is caused by increased calcium phosphate in the blood and may result from hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, or both.
    • It is commonly associated with hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, metastatic disease, and myeloma.
  • Dystrophic calcification:
    • The deposition of calcium salt in degenerated tissues in the absence of a systemic imbalance is called dystrophic calcification.
    • It is mostly associated with trauma, inflammation, or infection.

​​​​​​​Incorrect Options:

  • Metastatic calcification occurs in options A, B, and C.

questions.text: What type of calcification is likely to be seen in a 58-year-old man who died 24 hours after experiencing substernal chest pain radiating to the left arm, with an autopsy revealing an obstructing atheromatous plaque in the left anterior descending artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Dystrophic with normal serum calcium:

  • The type of calcification seen in atheroma is dystrophic calcification.
  • Metastatic calcification:
    • Metastatic calcification is caused by increased calcium phosphate in the blood and may result from hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, or both.
    • It is commonly associated with hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis, metastatic disease, and myeloma.
  • Dystrophic calcification:
    • The deposition of calcium salt in degenerated tissues in the absence of a systemic imbalance is called dystrophic calcification.
    • It is mostly associated with trauma, inflammation, or infection.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.

questions.text: If DNA is damaged in the cell cycle, which gene causes cell cycle arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - p53:

  • p53 is a tumor suppressor gene that is often referred to as the guardian of the genome.
  • It plays a crucial role in monitoring DNA integrity and orchestrating cellular responses to DNA damage.
  • When DNA is damaged, p53 is activated and can induce cell cycle arrest, allowing time for DNA repair or triggering apoptosis if the damage is irreparable.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - RB: The RB gene is involved in regulating the cell cycle by inhibiting the progression from the G1 phase to the S phase.

Option B - Myc: The Myc is an oncogene that plays a role in cell growth and proliferation.

Option D - KRAS: The KRAS gene is an oncogene involved in cell signalling pathways that regulate cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a sign of irreversible cell injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Amorphous densities in mitochondria:

  • Mitochondrial changes, such as swelling and dysfunction, are associated with irreversible cell injury.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are associated with reversible cell injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about apoptosis?

choices.text: Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways; both pathways activate interleukins
Cell membrane do not remain intact

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - ATP-dependent programmed cell death:

  • Apoptosis is a highly regulated process of programmed cell death.
  • Activation of caspase-9 is an ATP-dependent step involved in apoptosis.
  • During apoptosis, specific enzymes, such as caspases, are activated, leading to the enzymatic digestion of cellular contents, including DNA, proteins, and organelles.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways; both pathways activate interleukins:

  • Intrinsic and extrinsic pathways; both pathways activate caspases.

Option C - Karyolysis is present:

  • Karyolysis refers to the dissolution or fading of the cell nucleus, which is more characteristic of necrosis.
  • In apoptosis, the nucleus undergoes condensation and fragmentation.

Option D - Cell membrane do not remain intact:

  • The cell membrane typically remains intact without significant inflammation.
